factoid: The troops of the vanguard were stationed before Wischau.

The soldiers’ songs resounded more merrily than on the previous night.
Denísov celebrated his promotion to the rank of major.
Rostóv had already drunk enough.

Rostóv said: "Not “the Emperor,” as they say at official dinners, but the health of the Emperor, that good, enchanting, and great man!"
Rostóv said: "Let us drink to his health and to the certain defeat of the French!"

Rostóv said: "If we fought before, not letting the French pass, as at Schön Grabern, what shall we not do now when he is at the front? We will all die for him gladly! Is it not so, gentlemen? The officers shouted "Hurrah!"
The old cavalry captain, Kírsten, shouted enthusiastically and no less sincerely than the twenty‑year‑old Rostóv.
Kírsten filled others’ glasses.
Kírsten went to the soldiers’ bonfires with a glass in hand.
Kírsten stood in a majestic pose in the light of the campfire.
Kírsten waved his uplifted arm.
Kírsten exclaimed: "Lads! here’s to the Emperor and victory over the French! Hurrah!"
The hussars crowded round and responded heartily with loud shouts.

Rostóv was in love with the Tsar.
Rostóv loved the glory of the Russian arms.
Rostóv loved the hope of future triumph.
Rostóv was not the only man to experience that feeling during those memorable days preceding the battle of Austerlitz.
Nine tenths of the men in the Russian army were then in love, though less ecstatically, with their Tsar and the glory of the Russian arms.
The next day the Emperor stopped at Wischau.
Villier, the Emperor’s physician, was repeatedly summoned to see the Emperor.
At headquarters and among the troops nearby, the news spread that the Emperor was unwell.
The Emperor ate nothing.
The Emperor slept badly that night.
The cause of the Emperor’s indisposition was the strong impression made on the Emperor’s sensitive mind by the sight of the killed and wounded.
At daybreak on the seventeenth, a French officer who had come with a flag of truce, demanding an audience with the Russian Emperor, was brought into Wischau from the outposts.
The French officer was Savary.
The Emperor had only just fallen asleep when Savary had to wait.
At midday Savary was admitted to the Emperor.
An hour later Savary rode off with Prince Dolgorúkov to the advanced post of the French army.
It was rumored that Savary had been sent to propose to Alexander a meeting with Napoleon.
To the joy and pride of the whole army, a personal interview was refused.
Instead of the Sovereign, Prince Dolgorúkov, the victor at Wischau, was sent with Savary to negotiate with Napoleon if the negotiations were actuated by a real desire for peace.
Toward evening Prince Dolgorúkov came back, went straight to the Tsar, and remained alone with the Tsar for a long time.
